criticReviews.criticPost: You have my attention now, Warehouse 13.
It's a sci-fi/fantasy "who's who" as Warehouse 13 pulls out all the stops in a time-tripping free-for-all that opens the condensed fifth and final season on a boisterous note.

Like all good installments of Warehouse 13, it is the smaller moments that make the show so much fun. Pete's constant need for a snack and thinking about food are still out in force, and the banter between Steve and Claudia is even more sarcastic.
It didn't take long for both storylines to get up and running on Monday.
Everything feels more fun and it looks like the actors are enjoying every minute of their time together. Let's save our tears for the end, and focus on the positive until then.
This haphazard collage of genre cliches quickly overwhelms and does not add up to the greatness of the classics that inspired it.
All the cast seems to be enjoying these turns, because it's a show that cherishes the idea of going over the top.
It may not be rocket science - more like weird science - but Warehouse 13 is darn near irresistible.
Season one was promising and season two seems to be staying on track.
The new season starts off with a bang.
Far from suffering an identity crisis, Syfy has flourished with this kind of light entertainment.
Warehouse 13 remains a cut-rate amalgam of everything, designed to appeal to everybody, from steampunk die-hards (geeks) to rom-com lovers (women) to effects fanatics (kids).
Frankly, it's not so much exciting as just plain dumb.
Not too much new here. But there's nothing wrong with taking the old and doing it well.
Warehouse 13 is unapologetically and delightfully derivative, happily plucking the best stuff from our favorite shows and leaving all the heaviness behind.
The inventiveness of the gadgetry and the wild sense of humor that sneaks into the show give it the potential to develop into an adventure that's both funny and exciting.
Surprisingly satisfying, especially if you're in the mood for a light procedural with a dash of X-Files spookiness.
Kelly and McClintock pull off their roles in this precarious high-flying adventure, teetering between heaviness and humor in each scene.
None of it's all that original - the warehouse looks like the one from the end of Raiders of the Lost Ark, and Lattimer and Bering are like goofier versions of Mulder and Scully.
Good watching for fans of those campy, old Sci Fi original monster movies.
Basically it's a half-baked adventure series, but it's July, and fully baked may just not be the way to go.
There's a fine line between wink-wink clever and desperately cheesy.
Even in a medium where "new" is a flexible term, a new show should feel a little less old than Warehouse 13.
This, insidiously, is science fiction as extreme midlife crisis.
While the series represents an inoffensive stab at a sci-fi procedural, those eager to find true "wonderment" will have go shopping somewhere other than the big-box store known as Warehouse 13.
There were a number of lighthearted episodes that never quite worked. But the dramatic material was, and still is, formidable.
After seven seasons, The Closer is leaving the air in a condition that's far from its best.
Although a little too comic for some tastes the past couple of seasons, it is still watchable drama with a great cast.
The intensity of the storyline and of Brenda's final few acts were jaw-dropping.

There are many reasons The Closer has been a reliable hit for TNT since its 2005 premiere: decent scripts, a winning ensemble of character actors and, most of all, having Kyra Sedgwick in the lead role.
Tonight's return is strong enough that I won't miss the final six.
The show has just kept getting better as justice has become more personal for Brenda.
This is Sedgwick's show, a star vehicle all the way.
The Closer is still the same fast-paced cop drama. It's just that now we also have the subtext of finding out what road we take to the close.
Good start to The End and a major twist.
What would be an admirable message suffers for a lack of nuance.
Frankly, I love The Closer, the cops are like family to me after all these years.
Not funny and full of quips to make us giggle, but a deep seated story digging into the heart of the characters and what makes them tick. Very well done.
There's no doubt, no faltering, and while courage is a noble virtue, Brenda's implacability doesn't seem all that heroic.
By this time, you'd think we'd be tired of [Brenda's] shtick too, but The Closer has retained an amusing, compelling edge.
Sedgwick continues to give one of the best performances on television and is likely doing the best acting work of the summer season
Now in its fifth season, The Closer is looking a tad tired and predictable.
I've long thought that there was room and potential for "The Closer" to go from good to great. I think season five could be when that happens.

Kyra Sedgwick's Brenda Johnson is not only back for another summer season as deputy chief of priority homicide at the Los Angeles Police Department but also back from her surprise fling with ambivalence and prevarication...
It's good news that much of Season 4 will focus on Brenda's investigative team and on police department politics.
A well-balanced prime-time drama that has improved markedly from its earliest episodes.
I prefer the old-fashioned red herrings and comic relief of The Closer.
It does a fantastic job of reestablishing a real world environment while still presenting an investigation with enough twists and turns to keep things interesting.
Some gifts are just more than you really want.
For the most part it's an unconventional holiday outing, complete with closing shootout. Enjoy.
If the series is not so consistently speedy or violent as other LA-based cop shows, it does revel in other kinds of complexity, most visibly in its visibly "diverse" team.
TNT's The Closer is back for its third season and it's quite simply better than ever.
Although we're promised plots involving money, gangs, and sexual pathology, we'll really be sitting still on Monday nights for the variations Sedgwick rings on Brenda.
With the absence of [the] tension-filled undertones and conflicts, this episode comes close to falling into standard crime procedural territory.
It's just too bad the only way writer James Duff thought to make the character strong was to make her disagreeable.
Sedgwick's Brenda Johnson is a pleasure to watch; she's full of ticks and traits.
With Sedgwick's unforced charm and her witty iron-fist-meets-velvet-glove performance, The Closer rises to the top of TV's summer bill.
At first glance a nothing-special copshow, The Closer's ad-free premiere actually proves surprisingly entertaining.
This is a unique, deeply personal, and occasionally aggravating animation achievement... and I seriously doubt we'll ever see its like on mainstream television (much less MTV) again.
The 10 22-minute episodes on this collection's first two discs look great: all animated sex and violence, with a strange sci-fi sheen. It's too bad the story lines are mush.
25 years after its debut, Aeon Flux has held up remarkably well - remaining relevant in 2016 through its progressive depiction of sex and gender, dystopian satire, and mesmerizing art.
Some of Flux's images - a fly trapped by the lashes of a human eyeball; two tongues intertwining like worms in a wrestling match - still haunt us.
As engaging entertainment, it relies heavily upon visual splendor but proves painfully slight as a provocateur of futuristic ideas...
Like the shorts, the episodes are surreal and mystifying, and while the setups are elaborate and the characters well-developed, their stories rarely reach conventional resolutions.
Alas, forcedly cryptic dialogue, elliptical plotting and gratuitous titillation practically defy the viewer to get involved to any degree with whatever might be going on.
You'll have trouble believing your eyes.

Much better are the early, wordless Liquid Television shorts included on the third disc, each one ending (or beginning) with Aeon's death; they're far more satisfying than the later episodes' full courses of eye candy.
The best segment is a megaviolent but fairly cool comic-book action serial with a gun-toting heroine titled Aeon Flux.
Before landing her own spinoff series, Aeon Flux was the breakout character of this series.
Writer-director Peter Chung's Aeon Flux... is a shrewd, erotic parody of superhero comic books in which a scantily clad woman mows down an army of men with a variety of automatic weapons.

The cast does the best they can with the material, but considering how unbelievable the writing is, there's little they can do to lessen the feeling that we're watching a soap opera with nice production values, plus nudity and swearing.
On the whole, I'd rather watch my car overheat in rush hour traffic.
Crash has a noirish appeal, and ambitions to tell a big story.
The acting doesn't exactly induce gaper's block.
Leaves you wondering if the whole setup might not simply work better as a movie.
The show clearly wants to say something complicated about race and class in Los Angeles, but a number of the situations and characters on the show feel like situations and people we've seen before.
At once schematic and preachy, it never indicates the stakes - either for its "diverse" players or for you.
It's possible that Crash will end up saying something interesting about racism, cops, housewives, or Los Angeles. But I doubt it.
Unless Crash the show improves rapidly, it'll just provide more fuel for the people angered that the movie beat out Brokeback Mountain and Munich for the big prize.
Crash, based upon the Oscar-winning movie, won't prompt much rubbernecking.
Crash, based on the Oscar-winning movie, is a show that's madly in love with its own daring and importance.
The new drama Crash struggles mightily to appear slick and sophisticated and special, but the whole elaborate mess is just as leaden and obvious as the Oscar-winning movie upon which it's based.
Once you've seen the movie, why else would you want to be hit in the head with a sledgehammer?
Given the uneven ride, high gas prices are about the only incentive to stay home and, er, bump into it.
With six separate storylines following characters not in the movie, Crash could become a complicated serial.
... Pete Holmes has successfully created a likable standup comic (which is tough enough to create) whose struggle is something we root for.
It stands as an example of a series that the premium cable environment allows to breathe and grow and develop.
Crashing works because there's just something so inherently cozy about watching a person trying to piece together the A through L so they can eventually get to Z.
For anyone already hooked on Crashing, Season 2 should keep them coming back, and new or unfamiliar viewers will find their patience through Season 1 adequately rewarded.
[Pete] Holmes fills his character with warmth and understanding; you want to root for him. However, for a series about comedy it feels like it actually needs more of it.
What does Crashing bring to that overflowing table of meta-commentary about the stand-up life? Well, Pete Holmes.
Watch Crashing if you're feeling lonely but don't feel like leaving your house. And then make your friends come over and rewatch it all with you.
"Crashing" bore might be a good summary for this comedy in which little ever happens.
Painful laughs in this honest, scathing couchsurfer comedy.
Crashing deserves an audience. It is clever, witty and genuinely funny, working from the idea that the stand-up comedian is a kind of pastor to his unruly flock.
None of this draws a chuckle.
Crashing works because Holmes is so sweet (there's really no other word for it) that we root for him every step of the way.

Because it has a genuine interest in exploring what is funny and why comedians are compelled to do what they do, Crashing overcomes its rampant similarities to the stand-up-centric shows that have come before.
Crashing grows with its hero, starting off as more likable than funny, but steadily getting more laughs as it goes along.

Much like Holmes on stage, Crashing is working on finding itself. The premiere is solid and certainly has some strong humor at the expense of down-on-his-luck Holmes, but subsequent episodes get stronger and stronger.
It all makes for a perfect showcase for the star.

Pete has yet to figure out that the art of winning an audience is perfected through enthusiastically failing again and again. Crashing shows that Holmes has already mastered that lesson and has moved on to quietly, honestly killing it.
On top of it all, Holmes proves himself to be a strong actor and an immensely likable leading man.
Crashing has enough mostly gentle amusements to keep it on track.
Crashing is damn funny and very likeable, make no mistake about it, but it probably won't leave a lasting impression.
Crashing feels like just another sad-clown story centered on a white male comic.

At its best, though, Crashing is a kind of corrective, and an honest one at that. Comedy need not be only the refuge of the cynic. It also has room for figures like Holmes, for whom the craft is less a burden than a blast.

Crashing, Holmes' new half-hour comedy series, is exactly the material I expected from Holmes; a good-natured, funny, but not quite laugh-out-loud funny, inessential entry into the "comedy shows about comedy" genre.
The show works as a sort of trial by fire comedy about a guy who just might need to experience a bit of pain in order to become a better comedian.
OUAT season seven suffers from the same anvil-ish dialogue it always has.
The curse in Hyperion Heights feels a bit too forced while the alternate lives of Regina, Rumple and Hook seemed a bit uninspired and, honestly, not all that interesting.
We love the characters, but we aren't married to them because what we love most is the story, and boy howdy, do we have another story ahead of us.
Once Upon a Time's magic is gone.
With a new location and characters, the show is returning to its former glory.
For all the cliffhangers, and the sometimes campy costumes and special effects, Once Upon a Time has always been more than spectacle and cheap plot thrills; it offers a good deal of substance.
Season 6 of Once Upon a Time looks to be taking an even darker turn in the shadows of that enchanted forest.

Once loves to tell us that, heroes or villains, we all have the opportunity to rewrite our own story. It's just a shame that after five full seasons, Once Upon A Time seems to have tapped its own particular storytelling well.
It manages to set up an interesting new status quo for the show.
But the real emotional kick is once again between Regina and Zelena.

Let's hope the writers give the terrific Lana Parrilla a really juicy, truly nefarious plot to sink her teeth into. She's the most enjoyable actress on a show that boasts quite a few strong female performances

It's comforting to know Once Upon a Time is there as an entertainment families can rally around, and one that will challenge them thematically as much as it panders by playing in the Disney sandbox. [Blu-ray]

The cast is still superlative and the emotional dynamics between the core characters are still compelling. Everything else (like the plot and the wigs and the Charmings' track record as parents) is at least bad enough to be funny.
Fool me once, shame on you, Storybrooke; fool me twice, what the hell, I'm still here, aren't I?
Morrison delivered some of her best work on the show to date, and it's terrific to see the plot focus on a member of the regular cast.
Once Upon a Time's season 5 premiere starts the season out right, delivering on an Emma gone bad but still showing her struggle to keep ahead of the darkness.
With a smart decision to focus on the lead characters and not the overall "gimmick" plot of the season, Once Upon A Time feels renewed with a dark energy in its shockingly sprightly fifth year.
The fifth season is off to a good start, I just hope they can keep the focus on Emma and not go off onto a bunch of random tangents.
The quest to find Emma took several twist and turns.
I think this was one of the stronger season premieres that Once has had. The new characters worked well, and the introduction of Camelot was intriguing. I cannot wait to see what happens next!
This season's first episode [is] one of the best season openers of Once Upon a Time's five seasons.
Overall, the latest season of ABC's fairy tale drama Once Upon a Time takes an already complex and meandering story and complicates it still further by adding in a whole host of new characters.
It's rolling toward that place-you know, the one where TV goes to die. That the writers are trying to throw in new plotlines is only strategic.
Fortunately, Once Upon a Time's fourth season will not consist entirely of storylines that have to do with Frozen.
Now it's an hour-long commercial for Disneyland with the vanilla-est plot of them all, one that seems built on marketing algorithms.

I had no expectations going into this week's Once Upon A Time premiere, which featured the arrival of Frozen in Storybrooke. I was pleasantly surprised and enjoyed the human versions of Elsa and Anna more than their animated counterparts.
There are so many added layers that tonight's episode is only the tip of the iceberg. The intertwined stories and plots are quite interesting and done so well.
As much as I enjoyed Frozen, I do hope it doesn't completely take over the show. Although that troll was darn cute.
Longtime fans of Once Upon a Time could (or should) feel cheated by the show's latest tool to mask that it plays the same storylines over and over again.
There's been a lot of buzz about the addition of the Frozen characters to the series, and their introduction met expectations.
Unfortunately, I don't see much momentum for the Frozen season; it just appears to be an attempt at an audience grab to capitalize on the most profitable animated movie ever made.
It's still surprising the studio would risk such a formidable asset [Frozen] in this manner, but the stunt should help rekindle interest in a program whose happiest days appeared well behind it.
Whether Frozen ultimately helps Once Upon a Time will be a true test of the Disney movie's appeal. But we're talking about Once again, and that's a start.
It was a simple twist that I didn't see coming and thoroughly enjoyed.
We watch OUAT more for the villains than the heroes. What we can we say, they're just cooler and more interesting.
I thought this was a pretty strong episode, at least on the Neal/Rumple/Pan side. Good teases for backstories to come, some nice callbacks. Tinker Bell is a gas, but the cave stuff was a bit kooky.

It doesn't feel fun anymore. Each week feels like it revolves around the latest Disney canon character that will be revealed, rather than an advancement of the story or development of the character. This season is lacking direction.
On the way to Neverland, unfortunately, OUAT's season-three premiere gets immediately bogged down in family issues, an area where these Storybrookers have loads of problems.
"It's so much easier to get people to hate something than to believe." Peter Pan's words couldn't have been more true and that's why "The Heart of the Truest Believer" is so valuable.

But this season, the show kicks off with one [fairy tale] I think (and hope) will not only be great, naughty fun but will also help to aggregate storylines that started to feel scattered and rambling last season.
It's nice to have Emma front and centre again after all that "I will always find you" happening in Season 2.
The way the lands eventually intersect makes for a nifty cliffhanger.
There are lots of reasons to tune in for more Once Upon a Time this season.

By accepting its fantastic nature and going completely wild, Once Upon A Time has renewed energy going forward; it's not Lost nor Fables, and it finally feels like this show is living up to its unique potential.
I was happy to return to Storybrooke.
This series is strongest when it wears its heart on its sleeve, and I am a sucker for heart.
The cast would do well to have more fun (whistle while you work, people!), but the layered storytelling has its charms.
Once Upon a Time is a smartly-crafted reward for fans of light fantasy, with the right mix of cleverness, action and romance.
Not for all tastes but a few will love this oddball.
Once Upon a Time gets off to a bewitching start.
Fans of the fantastical can do far worse than Once Upon A Time, which manages to both stir the pulse and please the senses with its beautifully imagined medieval times.
There's gorgeous fun to be had here.
The show is not only great, fluffy fun, but note that it occupies a traditional family time slot on Sunday nights.
Once Upon a Time offers a mix of hope and cynicism, coupled with familiar television and film allusions.
Once the action leaves the overly Maxfield Parrish-ized world of magic trees and drooping pregnant princesses, things pick up considerably.
The pilot certainly looks great, and it's hard to imagine better choices for the leads than Goodwin and Parrilla.
For now, it's an enticing cupcake, but I want to see if it's more than frosting all the way down.
The series isn't very original, but that doesn't stop it from being relatively satisfying on its own terms.
Once Upon a Time is just as charming as a prince.
There is the germ of something really good here. And worth watching.
Once Upon a Time gets points for being creative and different, and I've certainly watched worse shows this season.
Give ABC credit for trying something different. But next time, try harder. And better. And maybe shorter.
It's flawed, to be sure. But we have to give it points for ambition: No other new show this fall is attempting to tell a bigger story.
Once Upon a Time succeeds on charm but comes up short on logic.
Watching the pilot again, though, it became harder to ignore the soap opera underpinnings and the twee sentimentality.
Once Upon a Time's square-ish optimism is what sets it apart from everything else on television at the moment.
